2539.96.text:
and me, and none of
us have-- well, sorry.

2544.76.text:
We don't have an MBA,
just a lot of grit.

2548.12.text:
So before I open it up for some
brief questions, any word--

2558.47.text:
Any words of advice for
parents of entrepreneurs?

2561.89.text:
Things you would have
liked to your parents

2563.72.text:
to know as you started
doing your thing?

2572.90.text:
SADIE KURZBAN: I have
incredibly supportive parents.

2576.41.text:
Financially, yes, but
emotionally, were so, so,

2579.50.text: so supportive when I did this.

2581.86.text: I am so grateful for that.

2584.78.text:
They saw that this was something
that I did with a passion,

2587.24.text:
and they were so
enthusiastic and excited.

2589.61.text:
They never put any pressure
on me about money either.

2592.05.text:
So it was never
about making money.

2593.51.text:
It was always just about
doing what you love,

2595.38.text:
and doing it with pride I feel
very grateful to them for that.

2599.00.text:
They also gave me a ton
of independence as a kid.

2602.01.text: So I grew up with four siblings.

2604.67.text:
They were both parents
who worked very, very late

2607.04.text:
and you know I was cooking and
making pancakes at age three.

2610.55.text:
So they'd leave
us $20, and they'd

2615.59.text: My brother and I'd walk to KFC.

2617.41.text: So, KFC or Subway tonight, Ben?

2620.78.text:
So that kind of
independence and confidence

2623.09.text:
has really helped me at work,
because there isn't a thing

2625.85.text:
that I feel I can't figure out
if I'm given the opportunity.

2629.90.text:
However, asking a
lot of questions

2634.72.text:
So still, when I get on the
phone with my dad, I think he--

2640.49.text:
you know, he's kind of a
neurotic person anyway.

2643.25.text:
He thinks it's like
our way to bond.

2645.77.text: It's like-- it's really a lot.

2649.52.text:
You know, every day, it's
like, how much money did you

2653.47.text:
I'm like, oh my
god, that is insane.

2655.59.text:
So he's sort of like
the nightmare investor.

2657.98.text:
So I would say, back off on
the questions if you can,

2662.59.text:
but full emotional
support and encouraging

2669.31.text:
AUDIENCE: Encourage
your kids to take risks.

2672.92.text:
They've gone through
Brown, they have--

2676.46.text:
Let them have their
time to take a risk,

2679.40.text: and it'll work out in the end.

2685.55.text:
SARAH CARSON: One thing
my parents did great

2687.86.text:
as parents of an
entrepreneur is they

2689.51.text:
talked about their
concerns with other people.

2697.68.text:
So I really recommend
that to the parents

2699.39.text:
out there, because of course
they're going to be worried.

2701.76.text: What the hell is your kid doing?

2704.64.text:
Don't talk about it with
your entrepreneur child.

2710.70.text:
And also, they found specific
ways that I wanted their help.

2716.82.text:
And they were helpful there,
but didn't try and help me

2720.43.text:
So for example, I would call
my dad and ring, ring, ring,

2726.24.text:
he would pick up, hello,
and I'd be like, hi,

2728.11.text: is this the Leota HR department?

2731.25.text:
He helped me with
all my HR issues,

2734.17.text: and I was so grateful for that.

2737.53.text:
So find the thing your kid
wants help with, and do that.

2741.25.text:
And then, my final
thing is, especially

2744.50.text:
if you have daughters, take
a good look at whether or not

2756.39.text:
And it's not about what she
looks like, it's not about

2763.83.text:
whether she's getting married,
or having kids, or anything

2768.37.text:
So my parents were
great at that, so hooray

2777.51.text:
and I'm still
working this all out.

2789.12.text:
But I think for me the live
tension is still like, oh,

2791.91.text:
we're so proud of you and
all of your accomplishments,

2794.16.text:
but why do you let nannies
raise your children?

2796.23.text:
I mean, that is to
me a very real issue

2799.35.text: in my life every single day.

2802.14.text:
And I don't have any
good answers except

2805.71.text: to cultivate a tribe of women.

2809.58.text:
And this can be
really hard, actually,

2814.65.text:
You know, if I didn't have other
women entrepreneurs in my boat

2818.46.text:
to talk to when I'm just
overwhelmed with guilt,

2822.34.text:
and you know my mother's
driving me crazy,

2824.16.text: or whatever, I would be lost.

2832.83.text:
DEB MILLS-SCOFIELD: One
of the things that I--

2834.75.text:
last year, I was
in Silicon Valley.

2836.40.text:
I was brought out
by a major archetype

2840.39.text:
out there to help their women
in tech rise up the ladder.

2844.32.text:
So they are women in marketing
business, which was fine.

2847.09.text:
But the women in tech, engineers
and CS, were not climbing up.

2851.28.text: There were a lot of reasons.

2852.55.text:
And one of the comments that
one of the guys in the C-suite

2855.85.text:
came up to me and he
looked over and he goes,

2857.72.text: you see that woman over there?

2859.32.text:
And he goes, well,
she's just really great.

2861.17.text:
I've asked her to mentor
my daughter who's 13, who's

2866.70.text:
So being the snarky
Brown kid, I said, oh,

2870.93.text:
so what's the going rate
for mentoring these days?

2875.97.text:
Well, what do you
have to lose, right?

2879.15.text:
And he just kind
of looked at me.

2881.91.text:
And I said, well, she's just
doing it because, you know--

2886.32.text: I said, oh, that's really neat.

2888.03.text:
So whose daughter
are you mentoring?

2892.59.text:
And I think as we
look out there--

2894.37.text:
so I'm saying this to kind of
you males in the audience--

2898.05.text:
if you're in
business or wherever

2899.91.text:
and you want your
daughters to be mentored,

2903.99.text:
whose daughter are
you going to mentor?

2911.34.text: You want to do some Q&A?

2916.25.text:
And I don't know where
the Q&A thing's gone.

2924.31.text:

question for Ms. Pingle.

2926.93.text:
AUDIENCE: Is that how
you pronounce your name?

2927.26.text:
AUDIENCE: I worked

2929.70.text:
My career is [INAUDIBLE]
so I was interested

2932.68.text:
in your presentation and
didn't feel I fully understood.

2938.15.text:
When you first started, did you

2941.63.text:
And then, finally have a
case and then get a grant?

2946.62.text:
VIBHA PINGLE: Well, we
started with getting

2952.53.text:
And then, doing
outreach with the women,

2956.67.text:
And the goal is to get
self-funded through the work

2962.46.text:
that we get the
women, so what we

2963.96.text:
do is plug the women into
global supply chains.

2969.18.text:
So the goal is to plug them
into global supply chains.

2971.64.text:
And in a way, Deb, that's
another place where I feel

2975.72.text:
being a woman really hurts
because trying to explain

2985.56.text:
to private corporations
anywhere in the world--

2987.85.text: this is not a US problem--

2990.03.text:
anywhere in Europe, this
is the same problem.

2992.13.text:
To go explain to them that this
is what the women are doing

2995.13.text:
and they need support
for what they're doing.

2998.31.text:
No one believes these
middle managers--

3001.49.text:
or the senior middle
managers, whatever--

3003.77.text:
never believe that the
women could actually

3005.73.text: be doing it and pulling it off.

3012.05.text:
For anyone who could have
any advice on this, how have

3017.06.text:
you managed making decisions
and being a leader?

3023.33.text:
that you're really uncertain
of what the answer is?

3028.86.text:
SADIE KURZBAN: Well,
I have a great team

3034.86.text:
And I just hope that they're
flexible with change.

3039.57.text:
Because sometimes at the
very, very, very, very, very

3042.03.text:
last minute when we've spent
a ton of time working on it,

3044.40.text:
I say, actually I
changed my mind.

3047.27.text:
So just rolling
with the punches,

3048.79.text:
and not really making a firm
decision until you've made one.

3052.99.text: if I could just jump in there--

3054.41.text:
I'm so glad you asked about
uncertainty, because that

3058.21.text:
was one of the
biggest things I had

3059.68.text:
to get used to as an
entrepreneur is dealing

3065.68.text:
But the fact is,
you have to act.

3070.16.text:
And if you wait until you
have all the information

3072.37.text:
and you're really
positive, it's too late.

3076.45.text:
Well and I will agree with that,
and I will say, it's funny--

3080.34.text:
and one of the things that
I love about my husband

3082.42.text:
and I've learned from him, is
he was an entrepreneur also

3086.32.text:
And I always joke that I channel
my inner privileged white male.

3090.86.text:
He comes from such a
spirit of abundance.

3093.96.text:
Like, I feel like
a lot of women--

3096.96.text: scarcity is very real for us.

3100.45.text:
or whatever, we're nervous
there's not going to be enough.

3103.63.text:
And one of the
things that I learned

3105.13.text:
from him and from other
successful entrepreneurs I

3107.38.text:
cultivated in my life
from my kitchen cabinet

3109.57.text:
is you just got to pretend
that there's plenty of pie.

3117.97.text:
Even if I lose this
client, there's more.

3122.83.text:
over years, and
years, and years has

3124.78.text: made me able to make decisions.

3128.78.text:
DEB MILLS-SCOFIELD:
There's very little you

3130.57.text:
can do in life that is
irrevocable except, you know,

3136.57.text:
DEB MILLS-SCOFIELD: As of
now, that's irrevocable.

3140.83.text:
But you know, even losing a
limb isn't what it used to be.

3149.05.text: you do have to just decide.

3151.02.text:
And very few of
those decisions are

3153.06.text:
going to permanently set
the course of your business

3155.37.text:
or your life for
the next 80 years.

3168.59.text:
AUDIENCE: I would just
like to add to that.

3170.38.text:
That making a decision when
you're not really certain,

3174.91.text:
it's OK to take
interest from your team.

3178.22.text:
AUDIENCE: And not be
afraid of feedback

3181.37.text:
from them. to free the dialog
back and forth so they have

3185.48.text:
the ability and the right
to say what they believe,

3188.27.text:
even if it differs
from what you believe.

3190.47.text:
And to be able to hear
without defensiveness,

3193.39.text:
and incorporate that and allow
them to be part of the process.

3196.46.text:
I think has been critical
to my business success.

3200.34.text:
Just wanted to put
that out there.

3201.76.text:
And in terms of one
more thing, on balance,

3203.66.text:
I think that balance
should be redefined

3210.01.text:
DEB MILLS-SCOFIELD:
Oh, that is great.

3211.34.text:
SARAH CARSON: I
variety of excuses.

3214.06.text:
AUDIENCE: --having one thing
to excess in your life,

3216.28.text:
it's having three, four, five,
or whatever you can handle.

3219.31.text:
that' kind of how I made it
work, because, otherwise,

3226.40.text:
about myself. what's
the matter with you?

3228.11.text:
You're not like
the rest of them.

3230.02.text:
SARAH CARSON:
Thank you for that.

3233.79.text:
I was wondering if
any of you had ever

3236.73.text:
felt like you wanted
to give up, and--

3248.08.text:
Every day, but you
know I started this

3251.77.text:
based on all what the
experiences of these very

3254.59.text:
poor women in different
parts of the world

3256.80.text:
who were starting their
businesses and running them.

3259.51.text:
And I sort of feel
this obligation

3261.70.text: to never give up for that.

3267.25.text:
With my privilege, to be able to
say, I give up, is just not OK.

3272.71.text:
I mean, here are these women who
are literally living from hand

3275.53.text:
to mouth, not sure
whether they can survive,

3277.75.text:
or their kids can
survive to the next day.

3280.12.text:
And if they're fighting
for themselves,

3281.97.text:
and they're finding ways
to make it all work,

3284.56.text:
then it's an
obligation that we all

3286.27.text:
have to find ways
to make it all work.

3290.10.text:
SADIE KURZBAN: One of the
most motivating things

3292.10.text:
for me is when I realize
that if I can just

3295.49.text:
keep doing what I'm
doing, I don't even

3298.40.text: need to do like that much more.

3299.69.text:
Just keep doing what I'm
doing, eventually competitors

3302.99.text:
will tire out, and we
will make it to a place

3306.45.text:
Like honesty, it's just
like persistence and stamina

3312.52.text:
AUDIENCE: first of
all, I just wanted

3314.37.text:
to thank you so much for

3317.39.text:
and for being so generous
with your experience

3321.77.text:
And, some really

3324.21.text:
I just wanted to add one thing
to the question about what

3328.82.text:
My husband does have an
MBA, and I have a daughter

3332.22.text:
and I have a son,
and I am constantly

3335.13.text:
having to help him
realize that he needs

3338.52.text:
to give the same information
about financial-- his

3341.71.text:
financials-- advice to
my daughter and my son.

3345.85.text:
He's a great dad, and
I think he's not here.

3352.26.text:
AUDIENCE: Right, but I
do mind that there's a--

3357.71.text:
And it not intentional,
but it's kind of built-in.

3361.12.text:
And so, if anybody has that
kind of advice to give,

3363.55.text:
make sure that you're
sharing it equally.

3365.97.text:
MORRA AARONS-MELE: I
just want to echo that.

3367.80.text:
And I want to say
one thing which,

3370.46.text:
And it comes back to the
whole issue of especially

3372.68.text:
if you get into like the whole
working mom debate, which

3377.27.text:
You know, one way to
shut that down is to say,

3379.98.text:
I need to earn
money for my kids.

3382.22.text:
And I think that women
have to be much more

3385.19.text:
open about the fact that
money is a reality for us

3389.33.text:
And that shuts down a
lot of these issues.

3392.97.text:
It's really hard, but I think
that it just makes it clear.

3399.33.text:
Like, I need to earn
money, just like you do.

3402.53.text:
SADIE KURZBAN: My brother
works for me, actually.

3406.13.text:
So we take meetings
together sometimes.

3408.71.text:
And it really dawns on
me in those moments,

3411.59.text:
because we have so
many times where

3413.69.text:
we're meeting with
a man who's talking

3415.31.text:
to my brother the
whole time, asking him

3418.22.text: And I'm like, I created it.

3420.28.text:
He just runs the
finances behind it.

3423.68.text:
But my brother is very
generous with that.

3425.51.text:
And he'll always
say-- defer to me,

3427.13.text:
and say, that's actually
a question for her.

3428.96.text:
And I sort of call out the
sexism as it's happening.

3431.13.text:
And it really dawns on me how
much my parents treated us

3433.55.text:
as equals, and
made me feel like I

3434.99.text:
had an equal seat at
the table as he did.

3436.70.text:
So I'm very grateful
to them for that.

DEB MILLS-SCOFIELD:
I just want to close

with one comment for you

So for you guys to

3460.69.text:
DEB MILLS-SCOFIELD: You know,

and on, man, it's

3467.78.text:
as I talk to my

you just come into it,

So don't think it's

3476.43.text: to do it when you're young.
